awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evolution of Early Metabolism: Carbon Fixation, Anaerobic Respiration and ROS Detoxification in the Anaerobic Vent Bacterium, Thermovibrio ammonificans
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria that can live without oxygen (anaerobes) and survive in hot environments (thermophiles) inhabit extreme environments such as deep-sea hydrothermal vents that resemble the early Earth.  These modern-day bacteria co-evolved with our planet, and as a result, these organisms carry both ancestral and more recently acquired genes and can be used as models to reconstruct the evolution of microbial processes, including how these bacteria obtained energy and the carbon needed to grow. To gain insight into these processes Thermovibrio ammonificans, an organism that inhabits deep-sea hydrothermal vents, will be studied. Integrated into these studies will be outreach activities for middle and high school students.  Lesson plans will be developed and used in after-school programs, in professional training programs for K-12 educators, and informal activities such as the 4-H Summer Science Program.   

Anaerobic chemolithoautotrophic bacteria inhabiting deep-sea hydrothermal vents are critically important from an ecological standpoint; by fixing carbon dioxide of geothermal/magmatic origin in the absence of oxygen, they are the primary producers in these environments. This project will provide insight into the evolution of early and acquired bacterial metabolism by leveraging different types of culture approaches (batch and continuous cultures) with comparative genomic analyses of the model organism, Thermovibrio ammonificans. Experiments will address whether an early Earth ancestor of T. ammonificans was originally a hydrogen-oxidizing, sulfur-reducing bacterium that could form needed organic substances from simple inorganic substances (such as carbon dioxide). With the gradual rise of oxygen in the atmosphere, more efficient terminal electron acceptors became available and this bacterium acquired genes that increased its metabolic flexibility - e.g., the capacity to use nitrate as well as carbon dioxide - while retaining ancestral metabolic traits (such as the ability to live without oxygen and survive high temperatures). The mechanisms of carbon fixation, anaerobic respiration and detoxification of reactive oxygen species in T. ammonificans  will be investigated using a combination of transcriptomic, proteomic and biomass carbon stable isotope analyses. This study will provide invaluable information on gene expression in T. ammonificans grown under chemical and nutrient conditions that reflect, as closely as possible, those encountered in its natural environment and will provide insight on gene regulation and expression in response to changing environmental conditions. This study is anticipated to help reconstruct the ancestral and acquired metabolic traits of this deep-branching organism and shed light into the emergence and evolution of autotrophic carbon fixation pathways.

por.por_cntn:
The majority of Earth's biosphere lives at the great depths of the ocean and within the subsurface of oceanic crust. This deep biosphere thrives under conditions of high hydrostatic pressures (>10 MPa) by utilizing metabolic and carbon fixation strategies that permit adaptation to pressure, temperature and nutrient-limitation stresses. The high-pressure adapted organisms ('piezophiles') exhibit a phylogenetic diversity that extends to all three domains of life (Eukarya, Bacteria, Archaea). Such highly diverse microbial habitats exist near deep-sea hydrothermal vents, where organisms have developed adaptations not only to pressure (>20 MPa) but also to sharp gradients in temperature (25-400 degrees C) and redox.

The overall objective of this project was to investigate the evolutionary history of microbial adaptation. To this end we are carrying out comparative genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic and physiological analyses of deeply-branching anaerobic thermophies, such as T. ammonificans, its close relatives, and vent Epsilonproteobacteria. We have identified the core (ancestral) and acquired gene complement in the genome of T. ammonificans and we have used wholegenome transcriptomic and proteomic approaches to investigate differences in the expression of genes involved in carbon fixation and energy conservation. We know that T. ammonificans can conserve energy by nitrate or sulfur respiration. However, while we have identified the nitrate reduction pathway, the sulfur reduction pathway is unknown. Using whole genome transcriptomic and proteomic approaches we were able to observe shifts in the expression of key genes potentially involved in sulfur respiration. We identified two terminal reductases of the FAD dependent pyridine nucleotide disulfide reductase family that are overexpressed under sulfur-reducing conditions: a sulfur reductase (NSR) and a sulfide-quinone reductase (SQR). Further, we have found evidence that sulfur nanoparticles may be the substrate for sulfur respiration in T. ammonificans.

We also conducted a series of high-pressure culturing experiments to investigate the pressure adaptation of a strictly anaerobic, NO3-reducing, thermophilic Epsilonproteobacterium (Nautilia strain PV-1) that we recently isolated from an active deep-sea vent at the East Pacific Rise. This organism is the first and only piezophilic Epsilonproteobacterium yet isolated and, most importantly, it exhibits the highest growth efficiency of all known piezophilic microorganisms. Genomic and proteomic analysis revealed that adaptation strategies under high pressure involve upregulation of genes encoding for membrane fluidity, ATP transport, motility and production/conservation of energy, along with the downregulation of enzymes linked to the reductive citric acid cycle (rTCA). The genome of strain PV-1 encodes at least six different hydrogenases. The redundancy of the different types of hydrogenases reflects the importance of hydrogen metabolism in this strictly hydrogenotrophic bacterium; a metabolic characteristic that is shared among all members of the family Nautiliaceae.

Most exciting, the genome of strain PV-1 carries a complete prophage. To date, only Nitratiruptor sp. in the class Epsilonproteobacteria has been shown to contain a temperate virus (NrS-1). In strain PV-1, the phage proteins were differentially expressed when PV-1 was incubated in the chemostat at low and high pressure: the putative capsid protein of the prophage, phage baseplate assembly protein J, and phage tail sheath monomer were overexpressed at low pressure. Interestingly, the long-chain fatty acid transport protein, a putative receptor for bacteriophages, was also overexpressed at low pressure. These results suggest that low pressure conditions outside the optimum for growth of this piezophilic bacterium could lead to stress, expression of phage proteins and possibly to phage induction and production of phage particles. Comparative phage genomics between isolates from Espilonproteobacteria (NrS-1, PV-1 phage) will constrain the ecological impact of bacteriophages and their contribution to the evolution of microbial life at deep-sea vent and subsurface biosphere.

 These experimental studies involved the participation of high-school, graduate/undergraduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and senior scientists. Opportunities for training and professional development were given to female and minority students. We have developed procedures and techniques to conduct high-pressure continuous culture of microbial communities. A US patent was been granted that encloses these technological developments. Constraining microbial growth experimentally at elevated pressures will promote both our fundamental knowledge of life in the piezosphere as well as the optimization of biomaterial yields or biological reaction rates for industrial applications. To this end, we have developed projects to understand the possible use of piezophilic chemolithoautotrophic bacteria in enhancing geologic CO2 sequeastration and microbial-enhanced oil recovery.
